author: f8038ff2-7078-5e21-b45a-5aef1a090542
content:
Persona 5 Strikers, while not like other games in the series, is still an incredible game in my eyes.
SPOILERS BELOW
-
-
-
-
-
-
-
In terms of gameplay, Strikers is akin to Hyrule Warriors, with the aspects of Persona gameplay mixed in. There are 4 difficulties; easy, normal, hard, and merciless, which is only available in NG+. Personally, I played on hard mode up until the Osaka jail, because by then, it took me around 30 minutes or so to clear out certain prison keeps. Normal is a good difficulty for people who are possibly new to the action format (such as myself) and I have not tried easy, but given that its easier than normal, its most likely forgiving. The aspects of normal Persona mixed with action style gameplay is interesting, but in my experience, it is very rinse and repeat. Honestly, I couldn't do too many of the special moves or master arts, because enemies always hit me down before I could finish them. It was much easier to charge Joker's gun, or just spam whatever the enemy was weak to. As for the requests and jails, it's a mixed bag for me. The requests are decent, and dont take much time to complete, but that's about it. The jails are interesting, but unlike Persona 5, they don't offer many hiding spaces for ambushes, causing you to have to either be ambushed, shoot an enemy from far away, or attempt a direct hit. However, they are more action packed in my opinion. Using the environment to do phantom dash attacks are quite nice and can create cool combos if you can use them correctly. All in all, the gameplay isn't bad, but it isn't spectacular either. My biggest complaints are that A. you can only see the telegraph for an enemy's attack if you are facing them, and B. you MUST be locked on if you want to quickly use a magic attack and keep the flow of your fight. I would, however, definitely play this over almost any triple A game made today.

As for the story, it essentially follows that of Persona 5. As a direct sequel (or spinoff? Royal makes things weird.), it takes place after the collapse of the Metaverse and after the Antisocial Force's semi-disbandment. Personally, I think that Strikers has a few loopholes that I won't go too deep into, but it does have some "aha" moments, but also some poorly instigated moments that just feel like a plot device. The story is still alluring, and I was invested the whole time, but some parts could have been a little fleshed out. The interactions between the Thieves were nice, however, which is one of the main things I like in Persona games.

The last part I'll probably talk about is formatting, graphics, ect. Frame cap is 60 fps which isnt the end of the world, but I did notice that Yusuke's showtime did lag out my computer occasionally, and sometimes when the camera pans out to a birds eye view or a showcase of the palace, there were glitched out portions of the screen, but that wasn't anything too bad. Nothing compared to the infinite loading screen I got on my rematch of the final boss :( But regardless, the game looks nice, obviously similar to that of the original Persona 5. The menus are nice, and the game has a lot of color.

All in all, I would still say this game is one of if not my favorite games on Steam, and for good reason. Every game has its flaws, but the world of Persona will always hold a special place in my heart.

Plus the music, too. Just buy the bonus content and listen to Counterstrike forever. Songs a banger.

author: 67182b27-f545-595c-8fda-34c507d7fdfa
content:
I went into this game thinking I was going to play a Warriors game. What i got was a Persona game masked as Warriors game.

I love the Persona series, but it works way better in turn based combat than in this basically real time madness where enemies are many and their skills even more. I also love Warriors games but here I can't get that almost immortal superhero 1 vs 1000 feeling as I have to dodge around and make fights as easy as possible with ambush tactics. Until the game throws me a boss or a mini boss with multiple times the difficulty I've had for the last 2 hours or so.

I really wanted to like this game as it combines two of my favourites, but I can't really enjoy either side of it as is. It might be because of my expectations: I wanted more Warriors less Persona. I wanted to check my brain out and play hack 'n' slash game, but what I got was more of JRPG game with clunky gameplay.

If you enjoy the game, good for you. But I got more frustration than enjoyment and I would not recommend the game at this time. Maybe when I go back to the game at some point and just lower the difficulty to easy I can get something from it. At this moment, I just want to enjoy my evening and not get angry at a boss fight.

author: 138b6ba0-007e-53ef-b77a-4ca9e8e0ae69
content:
[h1] Well first things First, [/h1]

 You need to beat or watch (a play-through I heard the anime isn't too hot) Persona 5 to get some real enjoyment out of this game but you don't necessarily need to do the same with Persona 5 Royal. From what I played, there's no real spoilers from Royal I think but there could be secrets that I don't know about.  So playing royal isn't necessary but probably gives some extra flavor with some interactions more than likely. 
Now you might be asking yourself

 [i] Why do I need to play or watch Persona 5? [/i]

 well my good sir, ma'am or whatever pronouns align yourself with, this game is essentially more Persona 5 with a side of dynasty warriors game-play instead of that classic turn-base Persona Flavor. [b] If you haven't played or watched Persona 5 this game will not be that entertaining for you! You'll be buying a game that's basically an extra chapter to the Persona 5 story. If you have done so then the bold section does not pertain to you. [/b] Continuing on, You're not about to get all of the social simulator mechanics that Persona is known for but you'll be getting the aesthetic, music, and main cast interactions from it. If you want more of that this game is for you as this game is filled to the brim with fan-service but not the NSFW variety SO BACK TO TWITTER YOU GO YOU FIENDS, but I'll be joining y'all later.

Now the for the main game-play...

Its not for everyone.

The Dynasty Warriors formula is not the most responsive game-play of the bunch. At times you'll swatting away at a boss with long health bars for minutes on end. Luckily, they spiced things up by adding some SMT (Shin Megami Tensei a.k.a the series Persona derives from) mechanics which allows you to exploit the bosses weakness to beat them but that also go both ways. If you choose the wrong party for a fight some of your party members will get erased from the surface of the earth but if you already played Persona you'll be used to it. You can still customize your party to whatever play-style that suits you so if you want your Ryuji to be a physical Damage Chad you can do so. In particular with the game-play, I don't like the dodge function in this game, it took me while to understand it but I feel they could done of a better job at implementing it so you can dodge attacks more properly. Despite this though, defeating massive waves of shadows can be therapeutic but as I mentioned its just not for everyone.

Ultimately I think you should watch some game-play for a final verdict, Seeing is better than reading and if you see what I'm talking about you might be hooked or save some money in your bank account. If you're missing some Persona though this game is absolute must-buy specially if it get on sale for a better price.

P.S

With the PC version the game was buggy in the past but since then I believe they patched 
 certain things up so if you see any reviews about it being buggy make sure you check the date as the game could of been patched since then or there still could be issues with it. My experience wasn't too bad, I do admit to have issues in the beginning when the game first came out but after a month everything was smooth sailing to the end.

author: 5d617b12-d9c8-5863-b469-cd27e8c587fc
content:
All the new songs and remixes of the old ones are insane, just like the in the other persona game(at least p3+), especially the new track Daredevil.

The gameplay is on the same level as original persona 5. i really recommend doing your first playthrough on normal and then play it on merciless new game plus, enemies scale with your level there, so its the difficulty where you actually experience the combat.

For optimization, its nearly perfect, i ran it on Radeon HD7800 series(gpu from like 2013 that is also in ps4) and i was getting 60 fps 95% of the time. If you have some stronger gpu put the resolution on 4k because the game either has dogshit or no antialiasing at all.

Story. Its a persona game, Also play the original Persona 5 before this, because its gonna spoil a shit ton for you, and you also wont know who is who and why is what happening.

Only thing i kind of didnt like about it, is the forced "Fuse by Result" fusion option from other games, and that to fuse some higher level personas you had to level some level 15 persona to 65, good you can boost them with ingame money(which is the only actual way to level them up because the xp they are getting is miserable).

Overall i rate this game 10/10 a perfect sequel, i dont regret spending 60 euro on this.


tips:  If you get stuck on the first bicorn miniboss because he oneshots you, its ok, just try killing him until you do it, and then you can continue enjoying the rest of the game. The goat is busted as fuck, he ís like 2 times harder than any other miniboss, or maybe even as hard as an actual boss.
        If you bought the old songs dlc, go to settings>game settings and scroll until you see what soundtrack you want to listen to. Select random. If you dont like some of the songs in there, you can turn them off.
        After you defeat the final boss and watch the credits, your save will say the game is completed, but it really isnt. Load it, and you will get called to the velvet room where lavenza tells you to kill all the bosses again, and when you kill them, you will get a request for killing The Reaper, if you do that, you will get an achievement, and will be able to play ng++
       You will transfer everything, except for some story items to new game plus, including your level money and compendium, so if you finish the first playthrough at level 80, you will get level 90 and fuse lucifer in no time.

author: 6c20f1e2-7f39-5e2e-9418-2276f35f1b33
content:
P5S is a great game, and even though it's technically a spinoff, it feels like an extremely organic sequel to Persona 5 with a different combat system. Highly recommended it to players who enjoyed P5's characters and themes. If you liked P5 for only the turn based combat and didn't appreciate the characters, P5S is not for you 

If you're looking to get into Persona, this is not the right game as it's a sequel through and through. Persona 4 Golden is a much better option,

I found the gameplay to be rather enjoyable and thought it had a surprising amount of depth. The hack & slash setting and Persona based combat blended together rather well. There is however, no real social sim aspect and there is no confidant system. That being said, the character development for almost every character is really impressive. The new characters are also very well done. As usual, the OST is an absolute banger.

Combat can get repetitive, and there are a few quality of life changes (accepting requests outside of the RV for instance) that would really help the experience. Persona fusion is also drastically simplified. There are only roughly 60 personas and fusing some of the last few takes a lot of grinding.

Overall, if you liked P5 and are ok with a new combat system, this is a must have. If you're new to Persona and want to play on PC, start with P4G.

author: 71cc971d-d994-59ac-a04a-eb3e0bb8334a

author: 471b40c1-463d-55ce-8ab7-189b562d356a
content:
Despite its flaws, honestly a pretty good sequel/spin-off to Persona 5. Probably one of the best spin-offs we'll get of a persona game, it's just pretty solid all around.

The cast of characters from the original game are just as enjoyable as they were before, and I really like the new additions of Zenkichi and Sophia, they're pretty great as well. Especially Zenkichi, he's probably one of my favourite Persona characters now. 

Music is amazing as usual in this franchise, all of the battle themes are bangers, even the music in some of the cities are really great to listen to as well. 

Gameplay is where I think I had a few problems with, as well as the story. The combat whilst being fun at times, I felt like could of been improved slightly or perhaps just not as repetitive as it was. Whilst I liked the action combat this time around instead of the turn based system in the original game, the novelty of it got old quick for me at least, and I didn't really enjoy it towards the later parts of the game. It's not bad, I just think it could be improved slightly (even if I'm not really sure how? I felt like sometimes the combat was just spammable sometimes with certain moves, or doing different combos weren't really rewarding). I still think how they implemented Personas in the combat was still pretty well executed though, but perhaps could of reduced some of the SP drain, as I felt that sometimes was pretty hard to manage at times. 

The jail designs were pretty cool, but most of the time, I didn't really think too much of them as level designs. They weren't bad or anything, just nothing really memorable. 

The story, even though I enjoyed most of it, felt formulaic and VERY similar to the original's. It's not bad, but perhaps slightly unoriginal and predictable times. Still felt it was interesting to go through though, and was definitely better than what I was expecting. 

Overall, I personally really enjoyed P5S despite its flaws. Honestly a pretty good spinoff to Persona 5, and you HAVE to have played the original to enjoy the game in my opinion, as it'll spoil you quite a bit of what happened in the original, and you'll miss some of the references. If you didn't like the original Persona 5, then I can't really recommend this game to you. If you were a huge fan like me of the original however, DEFINITELY get this game, you'll probably really enjoy it.

author: a86d708c-a9f1-5d58-b8e6-f9ad28234bec
content: After a lot of struggling, I decide not to recommend this game. It is hard to argue the game is totally terrible, but I spent 80+ hours on it.  However, I do want to point out some fatal issues with this game which lead to my decision. First, the plot is filled with cliche. The story is highly predictable and boring. Second, personas play an awkward role in the combating system: on the one hand, creating/upgrading personas is so complicated, but personas are not necessary for non-merciless fights. So, it seems that there is a complicated system of personas that you would feel that it must mean something, but it actually does not really make much change until you play the merciless mode. On the other hand, once you play the merciless mode, the fight is unnecessarily hard and tedious without the proper personas, yet, the right personas basically make fights as a cycle of releasing persona skills, refilling sp and releasing skills again. I found myself push the same 3-4 buttons in the same order for 5 minutes to complete a boss fight in the merciless mode, which is boring. The creator failed to strike a balance between non-merciless game and the merciless game as well as the fight with and without strong personas. As an action game, fighting is one of the most important elements, failing to deliver challenging yet enjoyable fights makes the greatest failure of this game.

author: 33151dfc-ef38-5280-85e3-1eab784a2a5d
content:
It's not just a spin-off, but also an actual continuation of Persona 5s Story (without Royal Content) - and it does it's job incredibly well in that regard. The Characters - old and new - are done wonderfully and work great with each other. The plot starts out interestingly and knows how to balance increasing tension with the relaxed feeling of a road trip through Japan. 

I have no experience with Musou/Dynasty Warrior games, but the gameplay is fun and snappy - a lot of switching between your party members during combos to utilize their strengths and weaknesses. It can get a little stale thou if you play longer sessions without a break. 

Also... The game is immensly more stable than at launch. Meaning I encountered no more crashes. Some cutscenes still feel like they are a little lagging, but the game itself looks good and plays on a smooth framerate. 

If you loved Persona 5 and want more of the characters then this game will make you happy.

author: 720735a2-d5bb-5642-907b-ca5bcf293233
content:
A game that goes beyond its inspiration, and accomplishes something truly special.

As Strikers is a sequel to a game that isn't yet on PC, I feel obligated to say that there will be marginal spoilers for the original Persona 5 and Royal here, at least insofar as areas that I will be directly comparing to with Strikers.

I'm a huge fan of Persona, and cited Persona 4 Golden as my #1 favorite game of all time until only a year or two ago. I love the focus on slice-of-life melodrama and cheese mixed with 'friendship is the true power!' anime goodness. The music is always god-tier, and the cast of characters are almost always endearing beyond easy comparison in the genre. 

To say Persona 5 was a disappointment isn't exactly fair, but there were plenty of areas it fell short in, not just in relation to its predecessors, but entirely within its own goals, that I still talk about with my partner to this day. While its invention of an entire district called 'Shibuya' was no doubt innovative for the medium, spawning many spinoffs such as The World Ends With You or even a widespread effort in 1990's Tokyo to more closely mimic the buildings seen here, unfortunately that same inspiration couldn't be seen in the pacing and intricacies of its narrative. To go into greater detail here would be straying closer to writing a review of Persona 5 rather than Strikers, but I'll simply say that as the credits rolled on 5, I was filled with no great desire to ever see the Phantom Thieves again. 

Then Strikers came along and- I wish I could come up with a better phrase- stole my heart.

Strikers' abandonment of the Social Link and time management systems that dominate the mainline Persona entries was publicized well beforehand, which caused me to be much more reticent about picking up the game. Would plot be taking a backseat? Would these already thin characters be reduced to little more than an aesthetic for Musou combat? 

If those same worries assail you, please believe me when I say nothing could be further from the truth.

The Phantom Thieves flourish under a much sharper and much more tightly-written story here than in their own debut. While nothing deeply shellshocking for the genre, the plot has plenty of emotional gravitas, culminating not just in these pre-established heroes. but in practically every new addition to the cast. People act like human beings here, not 'shitty adults' or plot automatons. The core party has chemistry and plays off of each other brilliantly, and are even given actual time to enjoy themselves and more fully indulge their personalities beyond the most surface-level of jokes based on their eccentricities. 

This story works in tandem with an absolutely phenomenal combat system. I've only had a very slim amount of experience with Musou games in the past, so I can't draw many comparisons, but I will say that simply getting through by button mashing is an impossibility. If you want to get through specific minibosses or even regular enemy encounters past the first few hours, you have to apply constant thought to your actions, thinking a few steps ahead, just like in JRPGs, while also honing your instincts and committing combos to muscle memory. It's an extraordinarily well-done fusion of genres that I very sincerely consider to rival the best in the business. Neither the turn-based roots nor the slasher reworks overshadow each other; instead, they compliment each other like sunlight illuminating a pane of stained glass, revealing how each individual facet constitutes a brilliant whole. 

I absolutely adore Strikers, and would argue it as better as most of the other games in its series, mainline, or spinoff. It understands its heroes' motivations better than the original game's writers, presents a beautifully innovative combat system, and strings along a truly magnificent score to lend each and every moment even greater impact. It's a masterwork of a title, and definitely the best game I've played so far this year.

Well worth every last penny, and so many more.

These devs deserve a raise.

author: 19388f14-051d-528c-b9a7-df7e9f74b9b6
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a wonderful continuation of the world of Persona 5. The characters maintain their growth and prove how memorable they are through dialogue, the story is a heartwarming romp across Japan, and the music keeps the funky flair mixed with newfound upbeat tempos and hard rock to hammer home the extremely hype show-stopping moments of the game. With a run time of 90-100 hours and then some for those who want even more, the price is well worth it if you are looking for a new action game to sink your free time into.

However, the combination of classic Persona mechanics and action game speed, timing, and reflexes, along with some new innovations or streamlined bits, creates a super cool blend of worthwhile progression that is as addicting as it is semi-frustrating. You can only get better at the game by practicing your moments of striking while the iron is hot, but when ambushes effectively end encounters before they begin when the Phantom Thieves gain higher levels, sometimes there are points when you are just waiting to put your button skill and game knowledge to a real test. It is a minor grievance, but admittedly this was an issue on normal difficulty for me. I plan on trying out harder difficulties in the near future.

Overall, this is a must have for Persona 5 fans, possibly Persona/Shin Megami Tensei fans in general who want an electrifying change of pace from the turn-based format that you're used to.

author: 660f58ba-8fe7-55ca-9de1-26dcafb1049a
content:
8.5/10 (9 if you are a Persona fan)
Persona 5 Strikers is by definition, A Sequel to Persona 5 (not royal, as it does not seem to have references to that game story wise), and its a damn good one at that. Even though the game was not only using a completely different Fighting system, from Turn based to Warriors Hack and Slash like, AND was made by a different company, the game at large still feels and plays like a Persona game. What Koei Tecmo pulled off to recreate the Persona style is nothing but extraordinary. Many of their previous warriors games, in my opinion, were just plain boring. I am not a big fan of Warriors games, but somehow they made Persona 5 Strikers still feel not only like Persona, but an actual fun game (sorry Warriors fans). Now onto the pros and cons of this game.

Combat: The combat in this game is simply amazing, especially for a combat system that I previously dislike. With the use of not only Personas and the Phantom Dash Mechanic making the combat feel unique and special each interaction, but also each character's unique playstyle and personality, while also staying true to who they are from the previous game. The game always tries to throw in a new gimmick or mechanic into the fight each time you progress in order to prevent the combat from becoming stale. Fighting large quantities imo is just plain satisfying, however fighting one, strong enemy can show the limits of the combat system. The game does try to spice it up with new mechanics, but it is obvious the combat was made for large groups, as slashing only one target doesn't feel as satisfying, and there were a couple of moments where I thought turn based would had made the boss fight more interesting.

Difficulty: the game was simply easy, a bit too easy at times but at the same time, would be hard. It may be due to me doing all the requests in the game, but near the end it was very uncommon to die, as the game had many many, many forgivable mechanics in order to prevent death, while also many of the enemies would telegraph their attack, allowing for alot of time to react and dodge. There was a Merciless option too, but that was only after you beat the game + post-game content.

Story:Im not going to dive deep into the story simply to avoid spoilers, but at large, the story was pretty damn good. Again, wasn't as good as mainline Persona games, but was still really good at the end and gave me the badass feel that the Persona 5 story previously gave me. The message of this game was also pretty good, tackling modern society issues, and having really complex characters, with none of them being just pure good or pure evil, but instead having reasons for their actions.

Characters: the Phantom Thieves has returned yet again, and I think they still were just as good as in the previous game. They even gave Haru much needed character development that persona 5 lacked in, while also making everyone else more fleshed out, while sticking to who they were in the first game. The New Characters were also amazing, as not only were the new main characters super fleshed out, but also the side characters and the antagonists were really amazing to watch and learn about. There wasn't really an amazing main antagonist like what persona 4 and kinda persona 5 had, but the story kinda went through the same story arc as persona 5 did, and tbh I was fine with it.

Music: as always, the Persona music is back and better then ever. The OST for this game consisted of mostly remixes of previous Persona 5 music, usually in a rock remix format. There was also brand new music for this game, and they were simply sooooooo goooooodddd. Idk how tf they produce bangers after bangers of music, but they do somehow. There was an issue for the ratio of new music and remix music, as I did feel like there was a bit too many remixes where they could had used a new song, but the remix were bangers anyways so I ain't complaining lol.

Small Nitpicks/Positives:
-LOVED how this game felt like Persona 5: Sequel, with just a new combat system.
-PC controls were awful, I had to remap a shit ton of buttons in order to make it playable. In the end I got it to work and made if playable, but there was still some issues I couldn't get rid of like how the camera was just either too damn fast, or too damn slow to rotate. I know the game was made for controllers, but whatever I am just that kind of guy.
-The Voice mixing in this game was all around the place. Most of the time, it was pretty good. Sometimes however, the Voice actor would be too quiet, too loud or even have a drop in quality as if they didn't have any noise suppression. It was especially obvious during the beginning segments, like how sometimes even the character's audio would be so damn quiet I would have to repeat them, which just sucked. It was however pretty obvious it was due to the Voice actors having to record remotely due to Covid-19, so I think they get a pass in that regard.
-from persona 5 to persona 5 strikers, due to the combat change, some things were nerfed or majorly buffed indirectly. The SP pool was still pretty small, that was just a 5 thing in the series and its back in strikers. However, items are just 10x better in this game due to not only having huge quantities to buy in the shop and around the city, but also due to now being able to pause the game and chug a shit ton of potions and food without the penalty of it taking a turn like what the previous persona games did. IMO I wasn't a big fan of this, as it did kinda slow down combat, but it was different due to the combat, and there wasn't much to do in that regard except maybe nerf the amount of items.
-The game also had weird PC port things alongside it. Its obviously a console port of a game with things like 60 fps lock, game logic pauses when you don't focus on the window, till you go back into the game, and even with max details, the game seemed to have an anti-aliasing issue, with characters and further away objects just looking pretty pixelated imo.

In conclusion, the game was still really damn good, especially for a persona spinoff title. This is most def the best spinoff title from the entire persona series, but I still think the turn based combat should stick for the mainline series going down. Even though I really enjoyed this combat system, it did have its limitations, especially with large boss fights that the other system didn't lack. Of course large quantities was better in this system, but hey. Other than that, this game is especially worth to get if you played Persona 5, as this is just a continuation sequel to that game. If you are a first timer however the game is still really damn good, but you maybe lost in the story element and characters as you don't know who they are and what they did before, as they especially make tons of references to the previous game. I still think you can go thru this game w/o persona 5 experience, but I still highly recommend playing Persona 5 First. The length of the game took me around 50-55 hours, which also included me doing all the requests that was allowed in first playthrough, which is a really damn good length and so worth the price of the game (idk why people complained it was too explained like ok lol).

8.5/10 (9 if you are a Persona fan), really damn good game.

author: 17ccc3e3-d5a9-5c05-8269-fe85c391bbc4
content:
P5 strikers continues a few months after the end of Persona 5 with spoilers regarding many of the events of Persona 5. Strikers does not contain content from persona 5 (The) Royal such as new characters.

Persona works like final fantasy in that each entry in the series is self contained but shares elements between all of them. Personas (The spirits/demons/manifestations you summon to help you fight) and other mechanics work similarly across the other games but the story can be understood and is grounded on an individual basis.
 
Persona 5 in particular is inception meets anime and Persona 5 Strikers tosses the turn based combat system for a real time fighting game with a story centered on travel around Japan. Outside the dungeons you advance the story and prepare by obtaining items such as healing or buff single use items and equipment and accesories that affect stats and damage. In the dungeons you manage your energy to clear objectives advancing towards the goal of stopping people from hurting people, just like base game 5. 

You have a nice full team with different fighting styles you can swap between but you're really gonna stick with the main character, Joker, due to having the most direct power progression and for him being the character who's perspective you'll experience most of the story from. As soon as the game gives you the chance I recommend just learning how everyone works. Exp sharing is on I think but people will still lag behind I think. You'll want everyone about the same power.

Persona as a series knows how to use a great deal of subtlety, but it's main ideas it will remind you of often, and loudly. The great music being the best example (Im looking at you "wake up, get up, get out there" from 5!) The story is about many things but remember growth and understanding are at the center. It's very anime, trust the power of friendship. 

My main enjoyment of the games' stories is that they help with introspection of ideas by having a wide range of approaches presented to you with many of their consequences and logical/emotional fallacies shown clearly.

Gameplay wise: Hit those weaknesses! Your auto combo does different stuff depending on which persona you have and each enemy has different weaknesses. Thanks to free abilities with certain persona combo attacks if you have the skill you could go entire boss fights not spending any energy- if you manage to survive that long and have the patience, otherwise press the persona button to pause the game and aim an ability. This uses SP which less items and abilities recuperate easily. Keep a wide variety of attacks available, fighting without hitting weaknesses gets expensive fast and every time you leave a dungeon to recuperate the enemies re-spawn.

Personal recommendation for a game mechanic I wish I knew about sooner, accumulated power: If you feel low power in the game fuse more personas towards your level cap. Don't be afraid if a persona becomes a lower level than the cap from a fusion, it will eventually get more stats the more you fuse the resulting persona. 
If you do a newgame + run...check the guides.
Haru best girl don't @ me.

author: cee57c67-70fe-5543-8100-33dcada72230
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a strong recommend for fans of Persona 5 (P5), but I don't think the game will be nearly as enjoyable for people who aren't familiar with P5's characters or the Persona franchise in general. The combat was surprisingly fun for me, as I don't really enjoy this particular genre of gameplay (previously played Dynasty Warriors and Fire Emblem Warriors), but it isn't good enough if you don't know anything else about what is going on in the game. 

But I am a fan of P5 and the Persona franchise, so I really enjoyed spending more time with these characters and meeting new ones. The story is good enough but I was craving a more personal connection between the plot and the heroes. The story was more intimate and impactful in P5. 

What I missed most from P5 was the time management and relationship building portion of the game, but this did make Strikers much easier to get through and it was a very focused experience. So while I would have liked to see more of this in a Persona game, I ultimately don't think it took much from the experience.

So an easy recommend from me, with the caveat that I think this game has a very specific audience.

author: ff7c9f58-4566-52e1-8511-40890302106d
content:
Ahh, Persona 5 Strikers, I've been wanting to get my hands on you for awhile, and now that I have, I can finally write a review. Now, I highly recommend you at the very least watch a playthrough of the original Persona 5 (Or Persona 5 Royal) first before picking this game up, as it's a direct sequel to Persona 5. I won't be covering the story of Strikers much in this review either.

Persona 5 Strikers takes place after the events of Persona 5, you once again play as Joker, as you and the rest of the Phantom Thieves travel around Japan for the Summer. That's pretty much the premise.

The gameplay is very different from the mainline games, Persona 5 Strikers is a Hack and Slash with RPG elements. The gameplay itself I found quite fun, and I definitely found a few of the battles a bit challenging, even on normal difficulty. 

One of my favorite parts gameplay-wise is that I never ever felt the need to grind for experience. I never felt too underleveled or too overleveled. The game also reintroduces Persona fusion. And while not as vast as the mainline games, it was still quite robust and intuitive. Dare i say, some aspects of the fusion I liked more compared to Persona 5. 

Without getting into it, the story was really good, on-par with most persona games. I found myself invested in not only the characters i'm familiar with, but also the newly introduced ones. And there were a lot of moments that made me visibly happy, sad, angry, and so on. And that's a sign that they did something right.

Content-wise, this game has quite a bit. It only took me roughly 40 hours to beat from start to finish over the course of four days, then again I played it practically nonstop when I bought it. I'm a bit of a Persona fanboy, haha. 

I do also plan on completing this game 100%, definitely. This game has quite a lot you can do in it, even in post-game you still got some stuff left.

The english voice acting was fantastic. I plan to play the game again in Japanese to compare, but I just LOVE the english voice cast so much, some of the deliveries were on point, and I laughed out loud quite a bit at many lines.

Of course, I can't talk about a Persona game without addressing the best part about the series. The music.

Good GOD the music. It's fantastic! The music is a LOT more fast paced compared to the mainline games. All the battle tracks get me absolutely hyped to fight. And the remixes of songs like Last Surprise and Rivers in the Desert, among others, were done amazingly well! I could listen to each track for hours and NEVER get tired of it! 

I did yoink the deluxe edition though, which means I got two DLCs along with the base game! So I'll cover that next.

The first DLC was the all-out attack pack, it gives you a bunch of skill cards, along with 10,000 Persona points you can use to level personas up. The skills cards were nice, but also a bit unnecessary since the game is quite generous with it's skill cards, doesn't really justify the need for the price tag. 

There's also the BGM DLC, it adds tracks from various persona mainline games. In my opinion, this is the better DLC option of the two. Changing the BGM can help change battles up a bit, and the fact that they remixed the battle theme from Revelations: Persona just for this game says a lot to me.

The Deluxe edition also came with bonus content on the side! Such as the soundtrack, a digital art book, and Behind-the-scenes footage! Which I find really cool! Watching the footage gives you a glimpse as to how much passion went into the game, and I enjoyed watching it!

Now that all that's been said, let's get into the issues I had with this game, it's mainly bugs and small issues though.

One of the biggest things i experienced was audio issues, in-game audio was cutting in and out, along with crackling and stuttering. This is most apparent when I went to shop for things and bought things over and over in quick succession, or when I was in a menu like the compendium and scrolling down from the top to the bottom really quickly. This also happens in animated cutscenes, which kind of breaks the flow of everything, unfortunately. It never happened that often during normal gameplay, but it was often enough to the point that it ended up being really distracting, Although it was extremely rare, the game would also crash, which definitely was a bit frustrating when it did happen. A smaller thing was various instances of voiced dialogue not matching the text box, and lastly, audio balancing with the english voices. Sometimes the english voice acting is hard to understand, they sound too quiet, even had to turn the music down so i could hear the voice acting. This was mostly apparent with soft spoken voices. I'm not too mad at the audio balancing though, since they were recorded during a global pandemic, so that's something I can let go. That's pretty much it with my issues. 

All in all, if you don't wanna deal with the audio issues and rare crashes, then I recommend getting the PS4 version, as it's probably the best version of the game. But if you don't mind the issues and want the convenience of having it on your PC, or you don't have a PS4 or Switch, then get this version, it's still worth it! The game is not only a fantastic one, but it's also a fairly stable port! I didn't ever have any problems with framerate either, which is a plus! This game receives a 9/10 from me!

I'm incredibly impressed with what they have managed to accomplish here. The overworld parts being extremely bare, but that's understandable with how many different towns they implemented. My only complaint is one of the dungeons is so long, they make new Requests available mid dungeon without needing you to leave for any reason. author: ddf22c59-53b3-508b-a984-099e47771a60
content:
Pros:

Good character interactions (imo better than P5 or P5R, none of that Morgana vs. Ryuji drama)
Gameplay is addictive as hell (no seriously, the base game is like 40-50 hrs but here I am doing playthrough after playthrough because I just can't put it down)
Killer soundtrack (then again, it's P5, you probably know what to expect by now)
More screentime for characters that were somewhat neglected in P5 and P5R, such as Haru and Yusuke.
Many characters to play and imo they all feel pretty distinct, useful, and pretty fun to play

Cons:

Writing (plot) is kind of meh, especially near the end, but it's not terrible
Sometimes freezes during loading screens (I've heard people say the 5th dungeon specifically, but for me it happens all the time, even entering/leaving velvet room, using shops, location transitions, etc.), which can undo your progress if you haven't saved recently. That being said, SAVE OFTEN.
SP/persona skills seem unbalanced, especially on Merciless mode; you have to use skills multiple times to break "shields" on bosses, let alone down them for an all out attack, but the amount of SP each character has is similar to P5/P5R, where this is not the case. Endgame often turns into a case of spamming persona attacks and SP items (the grind for SP items is real, especially since shops don't restock unless you do multiple battles in the metaverse)
Some controls are a little wonky (such as all-out attack, phantom dash, follow-up attack, interact, etc. all being triggered by the same button, with limited ability to create separate hotkeys for them). This seems to be a symptom of poor porting from console.

YMMV (i.e. some info that may be a pro or a con depending on the person):

No confidants/social links, no time management (you can leave and re-enter the dungeons at any time to replenish HP and SP with no detriment), no turn-based combat (i.e. missing many Persona gameplay staples)
This is a direct sequel to P5, NOT P5R (and the story very much reflects this)

author: 69397682-f631-5f86-acfe-87dd547ee3af
content:
I highly recommend it to whoever enjoys hack-and-slash video games with intriguing storylines, BUT you should consider what controller to use if you are planning to use any.

I use a Nintendo Switch pro controller to play the game, and I couldn't handle how they dealt with their button inputs. The game's telling me that "A" is "B" and "X" is "Y" and vice versa. 

This will be confusing for the player to use, and I don't see anyone getting used to it. Some might say that that button placement is ideal for an XBox controller, but the button mappings are displayed for the Switch pro controllers as well, like the "ZL" and "ZR" buttons.

You should settle for a DualShock4 controller or an XBox One controller (and heck, even the keyboard and mouse). Until an update happens that fixes the button placements, my opinion stands where it is at.

author: fb4250ba-4022-574a-9fc0-a1e0e52a6d97
content: Persona 5 Strikers is a very fun game. It takes what people loved about the characters and atmosphere of Persona 5 and made a sequel that was very enjoyable, but I will start with some problems I had. First off I can't really recommend this game to someone who hasn't experienced the story of Persona 5 in one way, shape, or form. The game does a good job of relating back to certain things in the plot for context, but you may not feel very connected if you don't know the content from before.  Secondly, the combat in the early game feels very repetitive, and not very satisfying. My friends who also played this game felt the same for some confirmation. You will need to start getting stronger and more versatile Personas before you start getting into the good stuff. This is an RPG so that's a given, so if you thought you could mash through the game it won't be that easy. Lastly, the story is kind of stale for the first chunk and feels like you're getting nowhere. Once the Phantom Thieves start piecing together the signs and make their way towards the bigger baddies, the story gets very good, very fast thankfully. This leads on to the good parts. The game looks fantastic on PC. The effects and landscapes pop with color and are a pleasure to look at. Also the mid-late game story is very good, along with the ending being very nice. An absolute plus is the post-game content. There are many requests you can do for stronger weapons and fighting harder version of previous bosses for a fun challenge. Though I had my issues I highly recommend this game to Persona fans, but give a smaller recommendation to new comers. Very fun, maybe wait for a price drop. 8/10

author: 167450c9-fb8f-586c-947f-2d9b09048fd3
content:
Both the best Warriors game, and least warriors game.

Persona strikers is a sequel to the vanilla persona 5 that plays with the hack and slash combat of dynasty warriors.
story wise this doesn't have any plot points related to persona 5 royal.

quick questions:

Which version should you buy:
Either buy the game one PC or PS4, don't bother with the switch version. PC and PS4 are so similar it just comes down to your preference, on switch, the loading times are like waiting at your local dmv to retake your license photo while the old man is yelling at the girl behind the counter on why he can't show an ID to confirm his states residency so you just have ti sit there until he finally leaves so you can get your picture done and move with your afternoon.
Its bad.

do you need the deluxe edition?
No. Unless you intend on doing multiple playthroughs and need variety in the music, there isn't any point to it. the all out attack pack gives you some resources that'll make the early game easier at the start. but after that, you'll be swimming in resources, so really your just paying 10 extra bucks for legacy music.

do you need to play any other games prior to starting this?
Not unless you want to. Play persona 5 or watch the anime, you won't be super lost here. the game tells its own story that takes place a few months after the events of persona 5, though your not going to be drowned in call backs and references to the previous game. Its got a few places it takes itself for a persona game thats a fun ride, least to say, you'll be entertained if you're in the camp who just loves persona for its story

How difficult is the game?
Playing on normal mode, its fairly simple and wont beat you to your knees after the first couple hours. you might feel starved for resources at first, but after the first dungeon is done, you'll be fine. Worst case, if you fight tougher enemies without their weaknesses in your party, the fights will just last another 15-ish minutes.
Once you go into new game plus however, your characters will die in only a couple hits. Its doable, though a clear difference.

how long is the game?
doing a single playthrough on normal mode with doing every side quest, and most achievments, just over 50 hours. For completionist 86-95 hours since you will have to grind a small amount near the end.
I 100% the game 86 hours and didn't feel like I was grinding at all until the last 3 hours. By far this was one of the most enjoyable games I've 100% as the pacing really doesn't struggle to keep itself together.

Now for everything else:
How different is this game from normal dynasty warriors & persona?
besides throwing out turn based combat and the traditional calendar system, your able to freely come and go from the games dungeons as much as you want at no penalty to you.
You wont need to manage keeps and battle enemies in hordes and dictate who should target what, rather you have a set map you can be stealthy and fight enemies in with your 4 party members (who can be switched with the entire cast outside of battles ) will join the fight. killed a handful of enemies and move on. "Keeps" from dynasty warriors have been reduced to simply plot points on the map rather than a part of the map to take that you dont wanna lose.
there's a clear simplicity from the usual warriors spin off here and its all the better for it.
Persona fusing is here again as you'll be getting sacrificing personas to keep yourself going.
all the party members are useful this time around and you'll use them all fairly regularly through the main the main story.

final verdict: 10/10
TLDR: a solid hack and slash that doesn't feel like tedious, even into the games final moments of completion.

author: f4f69e40-59a5-5ca0-bd40-188b69c58760
content:
I started playing this game immediately after obtaining the Platinum Trophy for P5R on the PS4. It felt weird at first, after 190+ hours of turn based combat on P5R. However, once you get used to the changes, P5S is a true successor of P5R. This is a true sequel, maybe not so big as the original, but everything is here: all the Phantom Thieves, all the adventures, amazing music, top quality voice cast and loads of fun and things to do. I hope this game receives the Royal treatment in the future.

Suggestion: Play P5R first before playing this game. There are a lot (and I mean a lot) of references to P5R that make you connect more with the plot if you know what they mean.

The only thing I didn't like was that Ann completely forgot about being my GF xD

author: 403c492d-c182-5adb-8e3b-e7c57efa40a4
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a sequel to the Vanilla Persona 5 (PS3/PS4) game NOT Royal. With that being said, to enjoy the full experience of Strikers. The player must've played/experienced the Vanilla Persona 5, since there's a lot of inside jokes from that game. 

This time around, Strikers is a Hack&Slash with some JRPG mechanics. Due note that there's no S-Links, no romance/dating options, and there's a lot of cutscenes. What makes Strikers unique from the other Warriors games is that it requires a lot more strategy. Meaning early game the player can't just spam magic attacks - which requires SP (Skill Points) to win every battle. Remember this is an Atlus game, they make their games difficult in the beginning to make sure the player understand the game's mechanics. 

Just like the other Persona games, there is a calander system.... eh kinda. While there are events in the game, Strikers is a very story heavy game. Even if the player exits a dungeon, no time/day will pass. Days only progress when the story progresses, so no need to worry about deadlines. There are some Social events that play out and trust me you'll want to get these events. Bonds are what replaced the S-Links, but these serve to improve/upgrade combat and gameplay. 

Overall, my experience with Persona 5 Strikers was a great one. I've 100% completed this game 3x (PS4, Switch, and pretty soon Steam). I will say there's an achievement called "Eternal Bonds" that takes forever to complete. Even though my playtime shows 30 hours, the game itself is about 45-50 hours (I skipped the cutscenes on steam, but not on PS4) its a lot of content for those who enjoy anime and/or Persona mainline games. I'd highly recommend it. Yes it works with the PS4 controller

All around good. It gets very repetitive story/gameplay-wise. I've played P5 and P5R and there really is no comparison.
I'm sad to see that there is no confidant system or relationships at all. If you haven't played persona 5 you might not get a few references here and there in this game but it's not impossible to follow along since they explain pretty much everything.
I honestly recommend P5 on steam if Atlus ever decides to do that.

On a side note. I thought I was going to enjoy this game more because of the real time combat but in all honesty, this game doesn't give me that "oomph" when you land a critical or hit a targets weakness. P5R always made me feel like a badass every time you showtime a group of enemies and in this game it isn't really all that effective. Especially since the bosses tank that shit like it's breakfast.

P5-P5R is just better IMO. I still enjoyed the game and i'm about to finish it soon.

author: 9e9188f7-fd68-5af7-8aec-22080b045170
content:
A worthy sequel!
I'll start off by saying that I dislike "warriors"-style games. They just don't do anything for me, but P5S managed to keep me engaged enough that I didn't really care what kind of combat I was dealing with. The battles were a bit more than just mashing the square button and had some variation based off yours and the enemy Personas which was nice. I think my biggest complaint is that the EXP share isn't a flat rate so you're forced to change out party members every 15 minutes if you want them to stay roughly the same level (which you do need to do).
I could go on and on about the combat, but likely if you're buying the game, you're more here for the characters and setting. 

It was great to have the gang back together (minus Kasumi and Akechi), and overall the plot was really enjoyable. Another thing this game did great was the setting. I thought I would be super bummed not being able to run around Tokyo but all the new locations were super detailed and interesting. I also have to say all the new characters are fantastic. I only wish I got to see Zenkichi and Akechi bounce banter off of each other.
There was also some more character development. Nothing ground-breaking but they did give it to characters who could've used an extra couple of minutes in the spotlight (ex. Haru)

All the new music was great. Obviously a lot of what you hear is recycled from P5 but that is no big deal since P5 has arguably one of the greatest OSTs of all time.


Don't expect to drop another 150 hours into the game like you did with the original P5 or P5R as there's just not that much side content, and story isn't nearly as long.
The game will net you about 45 to 60 hours depending on if you care about being a completionist.
Overall 8.7/10

author: a323e042-f92b-58dc-ba37-f6dcf6dec4de
content:
PREAMBLE:
I Don't think I can judge this game fairly. I Really did not like persona 5, neither it's main story or it's characters. All the problems I had with 5 are pretty much absent here. They don't gripe about adults every 5 minutes, they don't complain about society every 2 minutes and they also don't talk about how much better they are than everybody every second. I don't know if this game is great or if my low expectations after P5 make it seem great, but I do know that I want the combat and the writers back for Persona 6. 

GAMEPLAY:
Unlike P5, this game has active real-time combat as opposed to turn based combat. P5 tried to ad flair and look cool but it fell flat because the characters ended up just standing still and taking turns in combat. The sense of progression and picking the right persona for the job is still here, but with combat that seems to fit the story better. You have basic attacks. You have special persona attacks you can weave in with the basic attacks, and you have your normal persona abilities you know from the mainline series separate from that. This is what persona 5 tried and failed to make you feel, strong and powerful in the face of an army. There are also no more punishments and subsequent incentives to finish a jail in one day. No more time management YAY :D Time management was my biggest gripe with P3-P5, but it's not here.

STORY:
Do you want to go on a cross country summer tip with your friends? me too :,( This is just a group of friends doing exactly that, kinda. Saying it's a rehash of P5's story would be a disservice, but it really does feel like the writers saw the potential in it's story and rebuilt it from the ground up. No more cartoonishly evil villains. All of your "enemies" are all shown to have suffered greatly and as a result their desires have been twisted. In P5 they were "twisted" because the story demanded it. No more "I know whats best for society" main-characters. In P5 they were pretty much just like the main villain, but were never called out on it or made to think about it.
 [spoiler] The main "villain" this time is actually just the Phantom thieves, but on a much larger scale. He points out that they can't help everyone, that even now while they are talking people are suffering. He want's to become a hero for everyone, to help everyone the phantom thieves can't. His way of doing it is to basically brainwash people, and remove freedom entirely (just like the phantom thieves can be argued are doing to their targets) and when it is pointed out to him that he is basically erasing peoples humanity and becoming like the figure who traumatized him he relents. I am a bit sad that no one pointed out to him that he was punishing the innocent majority for crimes committed by the guilty minority, especially since there was a cop there, but compared to P5 it is flawless. [/spoiler] 
The characters never stop interacting with each other, so it really does feel like a friends group out on a trip. P5 did little to make them actually seem like friends that would hang out outside of Phantom thieves business, and while this does little to remedy that, it does pair all of them off to some degree. So while they may not keep contact with everyone, they will at least keep in contact with someone. I can see Ryuji and Yuskuke, Futaba and Yusuke, Ryuji and Ann, Makoto and Haru. Just like a real friends group, some of them seem to hit it off better than others. This felt lacking in P5, but there were at least more contained single stories I suppose.

MUSIC:
Yeah, it's pretty good. Some remixes from P5 to make them fit better with the real-time action combat. The jails all have personal BGM as you are walking around just like P5. The first jail has an absolute banger of a track, while the others do their job of building atmosphere well enough. The last one can be argued is alright. The battle music really gets the blood pumping and get you ready for a fight. It makes what happens on screen just feel that more sick. If you bought the battle tracks from the other persona games as well, then you get a good amount of music to make sure you never really tire of any one of them. 

FINAL RATING:
Standing on it's own: ?/10
Compared to P5: 11/10

author: 031a4d2e-48c4-5682-8ea5-1f544e72ab54
content:
The best Persona spin-off, the best licensed Musou game and a fantastic hack and slash. 

KT, Omega Force and Atlus did an amazing job in striking the perfect balance between mainline Persona's RPG elements and the action gameplay of the Musou series. 

Storywise, the game follows vanilla P5's ending and allows us to see more interaction between the Phantom Thieves as they travel around Japan for their summer vacation. Writing is expectedly weaker than the main game (as is with Persona spin offs), but the new characters and group interactions pretty much make up for it. I'm not afraid to say Zenkichi is one of the best Persona characters and he carried the whole game. Sorry, it's the truth.

Moving on to the gameplay, back when this game was announced, a lot of people were expecting this to be another mindless button masher like a lot of the licensed Musou games are, but P5S is far from that. Battling enemies incorporates P5's dungeon exploration mechanics to present smaller (when compared to a normal musou) but still fast paced encounters between big numbers of enemies. The addition of elemental magic, buffs and debuffs from the turn based games grants the gameplay a new layer of depth and more ways to deal with enemies other than melee attacks. There is some grind, but it never feels like a chore because the combat is really addictive and super fun.

As for the rest of the game's elements: amazing soundtrack (as is to be expected from Meguro) and vibrant and stylish UI and overall presentation. My only complaint is that the antialiasing implementation is terrible and if you don't force it with external tools, the game will look blurry and ugly. The port had some serious issues when it came out but most of them seem to have been fixed with the latest patches.

So, all in all, this is an amazing game. Bit of a hard sell to people who didn't play the original but for those who know what they're getting into, this will be one of the best experiences in the Persona series. Absolutely recommended.

author: 03ab9a58-c08a-5504-81bf-ca5a97394cc6
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a great game for the fans of the original Persona 5 game (and Royal). It is a sequel, so prior knowledge of Persona 5 is required to get the full experience. Of course, you could still play the game as is, but be warned that there are a few spoilers here and there so I would advise against it.

Gameplay wise, it is different from the traditional turn based style the Persona series is known for, that being Persona 5 Strikers is in a style of a musou game with Persona mechanics. This was my first musou game so it took a while of getting used to, but it was fun steamrolling through waves of enemies, and with Persona 5's flashy style and gameplay mechanics, made it a much more enjoyable experience. 

In terms of story, I'd say it's pretty good although that could be my bias towards Persona 5 in general. I do think that if you enjoyed the prequel, you would enjoy this one as well. (I don't really want to say much as I can't really explain without spoilers, sorry.)

Last of all, I want to talk about the PC port. For me, it ran perfectly fine for the most part, but it could be by many factors such as with the new patch (1.02), my hardware, and etc. 

For those who want to know what my hardware I'm using, I'm using a Ryzen 5 2600 and a RX 580.
The GPU driver version that I'm using is 20.4.2.

Throughout my playthrough the game only crashed 1 or 3 times but they were at minor parts (like an event with hanging out with Ryuji and Ann near the beginning of the game) so I'm glad it was mostly fine for me and I hope your experience goes smoothly. My computer also didn't suffer from the "infinite black screen" bug in the 5th Jail. I would advise to save whenever you can, just to be safe and to keep submitting your game issues to Atlus so that they could look into it and hopefully bring out another hotfix if you are still experiencing issues.

Overall, this is a great sequel to an already great game, and I would definitely say give it a shot if you liked Persona 5 but wanted more content. 

With the success of sales with this game, I hope Atlus and SEGA can continue to bring more of their games on to PC and multiple platforms. I personally do not see the point of having third party game exclusives as bringing games to multiple platforms will not only would bring in more sales, but it can introduce many people to their franchises, and it can make them more popular than they are now.

:D

author: 83795ec9-03da-5611-9b0e-89ed0c8566c5
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a weird game.  The original game was a turn based rpg but this is a action game with rpg elements.  Think Kingdom Hearts or Final Fantasy 7 Remake.  Strikers is an actual sequel to the story of Persona 5 (not even Royal but the original Persona 5).  Also the original game is still only available on PS4 so if you don't have a PS4 and want to experience all the story before this point you are going to be shit out of luck.

All this weird shit out of the way, the game is pretty dang good.  Gameplay is fast and tactical. Lots of fun combos and can weave in persona abilities in-between them.  The music features some original compositions as well as tracks ripped straight from P5. The remixed battle themes are probably the biggest highlights here.  Story is entertaining but can feel a bit too familiar if you already have played Persona 5 before (even the characters will say, "Hey didn't we do something like this before?")  The new characters for the most part are pretty well written and interesting.   Voice acting is great.

Now for my complaints.  This game can feel a bit too long especially with the story being predictable.  This isn't necessarily a complaint but I felt like more risks could have been taken here.  I also feel like there is not a huge variety of personas compared to all the other games.  There are a lot of cool ones here but it feels lacking.  A lot of the side quests are also pretty bland and lack creativity.  Kill X guys with X character repeat x50.  

So yeah, game is fun.  Kind of a hard recommend if you haven't already played Persona 5 as you will be in the dark in quite a lot of details especially character relationships and words like "Metaverse" or "Palace."  I would definitely recommend if you already played Persona 5 and are open to action rpg games.  7.5/10

Also Atlus just put P5 on steam already.  Why the sequel got here first I will never understand.

author: 51e96e55-46da-5471-a4ce-e2d29549e512
content:
So, I finished this game last month. It was a really amazing ride and took me around 50 hours to beat. 
And well I'll be listing some pros and cons as well as some personal "feelings" down the end. Keep in mind, I'll only list the really important parts in this review. SPOILER FREE REVIEW! 

[h1] Pros [/h1]

[b] * Good story [/b]
The story in this game is pretty damn good and works perfectly as a sequel. 
The Phantom Thieves reunite again to steal the hearts and desires of even more adults on a "roadtrip." That's about what I can say without spoilers. 

[b] * The gameplay and 60fps! [/b]
Unlike all the other Persona games, this one isn't turnbased. It's a hack and slash type of game, but it does it kinda differently. You'll still have to hit the enemies' weaknesses to do more damage and stun them, meaning you still have to think, it'll just be a bit more action-paced. And the combat is also really satisfying. Oh. Did I mention that this game is actually in 60fps? No 30fps cap. 

[b] * Visuals and cutscenes look better than they've ever been! [/b]
[b] * The level design [/b]

[h1] Cons [/h1]

[b] * The repetitive story. [/b]
This story is really good! But! This Persona game does like every other Persona game, it keeps the same formular in the story. For example, in Persona 5/Royal you go and infiltrate palaces, but most of the palaces are made for you to get another teammate on your team. While this game doesn't exactly do this, it does it in a similar way. You go to jail, turn the shadow good, and then leave again, only to do the same process over and over. While this ain't THAT bad, I really hope that the future Persona games will improve on this. This is why the last bosses in Persona are always so good, because they're so different. 

[b] * No social links [/b]
Makes sense, since this is a very linear game in comparison to Persona 5. Still, I've always loved the social aspect of the Persona series. Sucks that it ain't here since it's what made Persona 5 into my favorite game. 

[h1] Thoughts [/h1]
I really enjoyed this game and I think it's a GREAT sequel. (With a few flaws.) If you love the Persona games (or just love Persona 5) You'll like this game, 100%! It might not be AS good as Persona 5/Royal, but it's still worth playing!

author: 2f1bb7ed-a783-52db-bd5a-e99f96a7be8d
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is an ARPG triumph and hopefully a template for more SMT action RPGs in the future (it's been too long since the Raidou games).  They took the rough Dynasty Warriors/Musou template, merged with the SMT framework and Persona 5 specific features (baton passes, One More attacks, etc), loaded up each Phantom Thief with a moveset unique and fitting to them, and set you loose.  Combat is fast and fluid, while still being tactical and having that SMT lethality that you expect.  On an overall systems level, they kept what made sense from the base game, while removing or replacing bits that wouldn't make sense (ex. Social links, strict time scheduling).  The result is a game that's paced well, has a lot of challenging and fun encounters, but rewards your growth and skill over time (and your ability to fuse personas with elemental drains and physical/gun attack skills in tandem).

Plotwise, P5S is a direct sequel to Persona 5 (Royal content notwithstanding) and follows a similar enough trajectory as bit of a mirror to the Phantom Thieves' previous Metaverse adventures.  Strikers has the Phantom Thieves go on a summer road trip around Japan dealing with mysterious Jails that are appearing in concert with minor change of heart outbreaks.  In short, it's exactly what you'd expect from your favorite loudmouthed idiot social reformers on vacation, with some hilarious moments and the usual levels of "Morgana makes stuff up about the Metaverse that ends up being accurate".  Haru in particular is a riot due to not being saddled with the worst introduction plotline in the base game, and the new additions to the roster fit right into the group dynamic.  P5S won't break any new ground, but if you finished Persona 5 and want to spend more time with this group of miscreants, you'll have a good time with them here.

All in all, more than worth the money for SMT/P5 fans; if you're not familiar with P5 but are intrigued by this and don't mind some spoilers to the base game, it's still worth a look.

author: 14b1082a-1eaf-5627-ba63-c60952583c32
content:
Hi, I really looked forward to playing this game. Can't recommend it after 10 hours, though. I don't want to continue this. Note: I have not played Persona before, but have watched it on Twitch regularly and roughly know the plot. Also, I'll try to be the devil's advocate here, but don't blame me if I get a little worked up.
Pros:
There's no doubt it has awesome cinematics, cool fighting mechanics and controls well. I like Anime. Occasionally, I'll watch one. It's tiring though, how in every new Anime, most of the same ideas always get recycled. Persona, on the other hand, does a good job to come up with interesting new ideas and the characters all have a unique charme to them.
The palaces are really fun. I like the hidden chests and objects, the relatively unique combat ideas and the Persona system.
I played the game on normal mode and it is very well balanced. Plus, the music is great. I do believe some people are overrating the music, but it's still really spicy.
Cons:
Hear me out; I already mentioned that I like Anime. I, too, can invest lots of my time into deeper story and plot analysis. However, if I wanted to play a visual novel, I just would've. The dialogue scenes are cool at first, but they get so boring. At the same time, neither have any of my dialogue 'decisions' made ANY difference on the plot whatsoever, nor am I really willing to completely 'skip' all of them since then I'd have no idea what's going on. And the plot is what people always praise the series for, innit? I don't think it's bad to have long dialogue sequences, but they really OVERDID IT with the frequency. I've spent less time in dialogue sequences in all Life Is Strange games that have been released...
Furthermore, one is SO limited! I can't underscore this enough. You can't even explore one shop, one sideroad, one small area without any of the characters becoming professor oak lamenting about it 'neither being the right place, nor time'. I have to strictly follow the game's idea of how it wants to be played. It's frustrating. Why, devs? Well, in Pokemon Red (1999) at leat you could enter Pokemarts. Well, ATLUS didn't even bother to animate that in 2021. Again, where is the love? If the game is set in Tokyo, at least try to make it feel like there's a cool shopping experience you can have. The food and medical items you can buy in Persona 5 Strikers are basically all the same (When it comes to TP and SP restoring), they just have different names. By the way, 'Donut-Worry' (restores some health) is the only item/thing in the game that has made me chuckle. Though likeable, the convos are never really... funny. Yeah, the don't have a good sense of humour.
The areas are well designed. The artwork and visuals fit perfectly. In Tokyo and other places like Sendai, however, you'll see the same 9-10 character models all the time. Humans in this game appear to be nothing but strange hollows without even a glimpse of a soul. I just really wish they (the devs) had spent more time creating a world that's actually vivid. I wish they had taken more time to make this a good game.
The skill tree in this game is ridiculously uncomplex (It's the complete opposite to a game like Final Fantasy X). It's not interesting, it's not individual, and it's not really challenging your decisionmaking/brain either. Heck, they don't even make you do a small minigame or the like when you cook for the rest of the party. 
Hyrule Warrios, for anyone who's played that, really sucks at the plot part. But at least I get to PLAY the GAME. And I don't want to wait until I've gained freedom of movement potentially towards the end game. That's simply not a point.
We're in 2021 and still nobody expects your game to be as detailed as, say, the Witcher III (2015). In Contrast, with games like The Witcher existing (not a 60 Euro title by the way), how can you even legitimize putting so few love into your towns that you could basically copy from reality and didn't have to make up entirely.
Conclusion:
I have to add, that the voice acting in this game is superb and the writing too. As english is my second language, I quite enjoy the narrative and style. To be honest, I could probably forget about the cons. Well, if this weren't a 60 Euro game, that is!
I bought this game on Sale (52 Euro for Digital Deluxe) and that wasn't even worth it. I think at it's current state, the game isn't worth any more than 25 Euro, for there is a huge lack in love for the design of player independence. And hence they try to make it seem like your decision matters in conversations, you can't tell me they're not actually trying to establish the illusion that you do have some independence in this game.
Since I'm done with school now, soon to be studying at university and thus am short on money, I'll have to continue this game. I merely don't have the money to buy another one. I'll come back to this review once finished. 
If at all, please keep the comments neutral and respectful. Try convincing me rather than defending your favorite nostalgic franchise.

author: 6195eb6b-9935-507a-9fef-c4a0da53c2c3
content:
[h1] Actual, Super-Serious Persona 5 Strikers Review: [/h1]

[strike] it's ok, i guess. [/strike]



TL;DR: It's a good game, and I don't recommend it for those who haven't played/experienced Persona 5 in any form or fashion.



P5S is a great sequel for both the base and the Royal re-release versions of Persona 5. Admittedly I [i] am [/i] biased, as I fell in love with this game series since Royal's release and quarantine's abundance of free time. 

It has more of the characters that you love and more of the strategies you employed in P5, all wrapped up with fast-paced hack n' slash gameplay and a decent story that adds new characters that I'll refrain from mentioning any further. If this is your first game with the Phantom Thieves, I sincerely recommend that you [i] not [/i] start here, as all the pre-existing characters are already established in this sequel, and the game wastes [i] no [/i] time re-introducing them or their character arcs. If you don't understand what's going on from the beginning, you'll have to catch up on a lot in your own time, or just run around like a headless chicken and beat the h#%l out of the computer pixels with your skillful excellent button pressing.

My first run-through of mastering the game (Finishing the story and completing [b] all [/b] of the requests, side-bosses, etc.) took me exactly 69 [spoiler] nice [/spoiler] hours and so-and-so minutes on Hard mode, though I certainly took my time.

I also went through a Merciless NG+ run (only available after Mastering your first run) to finish my achievements list and unlock more powerful [strike] psychological Pokémon [/strike] Personas, I finished the achievement list at my current playtime (130.0 hours). While I do love this game, I'm not the type to normally enjoy NG+ runs and that more or less remains the same. I wouldn't recommend it, unless you [i] absolutely [/i] thought the game was too easy. Though be warned, it may feel a lot grindier than the normal Easy/Normal/Hard mode runs.

Other notable things worth mentioning:
[list]
[*]I only played on controller, and I recommend you do the same if possible. I'm not familiar with MnK controls, though I hear they're not the best. That preference is up to you, of course.
[*]The music, as always, is a banger. And has been remixed to fit with this game's faster, more action-oriented combat.
[*]The fusion system, the Velvet Room, and obtaining masks work somewhat differently compared to P5/P5R, though personally I didn't find the changes of serious significance.
[*]There are [i] no [/i] Confidants/Social Links, in its place are the traditional RPG-like leveling up of skills, and Combat Mastery by playing different Phantom Thieves.
[*]Speaking of which, you're able to play as any of the Phantom Thieves almost immediately. Each member has their own special variation of combos, and a unique combat skill that can alter your approach to a fight.
[*]Unfortunately, no waifu is canon. But (actual semi-spoiler) [spoiler] a certain 5head bestgirl(?) may or may not get more screentime [/spoiler]. 
[/list]


All in all, Persona 5 Strikers burned my bread, revealed the troof, and stole my heart. I lost the mutual respect of my friend groups after they saw me jump into the Persona sinkhole, and after 100%'ing this game I can tell you I've only sunk in further.

author: b0750583-55e7-5662-be17-53916d4e0ccf
content:
I was pretty hyped to get this game when it came out, in fact it's one of the few games I actually preordered because I knew I was getting it no matter what, since I loved persona 3,4 and 5. Plus I really like hack and slash type games, like Metal Gear Rising and Bayonetta. This however, is neither of those.

This game is a mix of Persona 5 and Musou games. If you like Musou games, you will probably like this, if you don't, but you enjoy persona 5, you might still enjoy it, given that it does differentiate in some aspects

It plays like persona 5 in the sense that you get to wield personas and it adds a somewhat complex layer to the game
However,  it's pretty boring as far as action games go. It's an average at best game covered with persona 5 elements that makes it seem better than it actually is.

 It lacks the polish most persona games have. The bad guys are bland, the main cast interactions feel sameish all throughout the game, the side missions are tedious as all hell, honestly it's a very unrewarding experience. There is no calendar system, there is no confidants, the difficulty is inconsistent... It's just not persona, or a fun game for that matter.

It's not good. It's not bad either, it's just ok! Not worth the $60 price tag, get it on sale.
